manuscript_citation: {"blocks":[{"key":"76mf5","text":"Kiemen, A.L., Braxton, A.M., Grahn, M.P. et al. CODA: quantitative 3D reconstruction of large tissues at cellular resolution. Nat Methods 19, 1490–1499 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41592-022-01650-9","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":41,"length":6},{"style":"italic","offset":126,"length":11},{"style":"bold","offset":138,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7u4a1","text":"MATLAB MATLAB (mathworks.com)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":7,"length":22}],"data":{}},{"key":"41f7k","text":"Image processing toolbox Image Processing Toolbox - MATLAB (mathworks.com)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":25,"length":49}],"data":{}},{"key":"djoam","text":"Deep learning toolbox Deep Learning Toolbox - MATLAB (mathworks.com)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":22,"length":46}],"data":{}},{"key":"62fia","text":"MATLAB - Resnet50 model MATLAB resnet50 (mathworks.com)","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":3,"offset":24,"length":31}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"7EABDC85ED3B11EE9FCF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.mathworks.com/products/matlab.html"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8D7F0371ED3B11EE9FCF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.mathworks.com/products/image-processing.html"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"983E02A8ED3B11EE9FCF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.mathworks.com/products/deep-learning.html"}},"3":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"D78178ECED3B11EE9FCF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.mathworks.com/help/deeplearning/ref/resnet50.html"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"e1gvd","text":"Codes are available at the following GitHub: CODA Github Repository","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":45,"length":22}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"21376869ED3C11EE9FCF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://github.com/ashleylk/CODA/tree/main/update%2012-13-2023"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bsf7o","text":"Here, we discuss application to a sample dataset “lungs”,\ncontaining 150 serial histological images. Download the sample dataset (serial\nimages and sample annotations) here: Lung Sample Dataset on Google Drive","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":174,"length":35}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"61C648BAED3C11EE9FCF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1K-wY_ArVGbEhebQD4AjOeERwx6-4Fw3G?usp=sharing"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6gsdc","text":"Images are .ndpi format and were scanned at 20x\nmagnification (approximately 0.5 micron / pixel resolution), spaced 10 micron\napart. Save the images in a local drive folder (e.g. \\\\Users\\Ashley\\Documents\\lungs).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":179,"length":32}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":179,"length":30}],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8D37360EED3C11EE9FCF0A58A9FEAC02","url":"file://Users/Ashley/Documents/lungs"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8rf97","text":"Filenames for each image should be created such that tissue\nsections are read consecutively by Matlab. Therefore, include zero-padding in\nnumerical indices.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3pjiu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2tf0h","text":"CORRECT FILENAMES: lungs_001.ndpi, lungs_002.ndpi, ..., lungs_011.ndpi","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":19},{"style":"bold","offset":19,"length":51}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eee1e","text":"INCORRECT FILENAMES (no zero padding): lungs_1.ndpi, lungs_2.ndpi, ..., lungs_11.ndpi","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"UNDERLINE","offset":0,"length":39},{"style":"bold","offset":39,"length":46}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"fcvr5","text":"The function create_downsampled_tif_images will create downsampled copies of the .ndpi files by directly loading each high-resolution images in tiles and down sampling it to the desired pixel\nresolutions. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":13,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"80gbf","text":"First, decide the resolution of the images you want to create. Here, we create images of 1 micron / pixel, 2 microns / pixel, and 10 micron / pixel resolution: ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":159,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"52sp5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f9sqi","text":"ds=[1 2 10];","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"3aib6","text":"Next, decide on the name of the output folders for each of the downsampled images you create. Here, we will save the images downsampled to 1 micron / pixel in a folder named “10x”, the images downsampled to 2 micron / pixel in a folder named “5x,” and the images downsampled to 10 micron / pixel in a folder named “1x.”","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"23dct","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c4606","text":"subfolders=[\"10x\" \"5x\" \"1x\"];","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":29}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"9mkto","text":"Using this function, you will make two subfolders within the original folder containing the .ndpi images. One subfolder named “10x” containing the 20x images downsampled by a factor of 2. The other subfolder named “1x” containing the 20x images downsampled by a factor of 20. Most calculations will be performed on these tif images. Note: here we use 10x and 1x for example, but other resolutions could be created as\ndesired.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9aq0c","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6fo39","text":"pth10x=[pth,'10x'];","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dnduj","text":"pth1x=[pth,'1x'];","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":17}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bru7n","text":"**Note: If this code fails due to memory constraints on your computer, try python Openslide.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":92}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
